Okay, Everyday Astronaut/Tim. PLEASE READ. I have a story very similar to yours, I was about 7 when I slept on a trampoline under the stars in my backyard except. I couldn't sleep! I was absolutely ENTHRALLED with the stars! Then when I was about 11 my church in Texas threw a Space-Themed cake walk sale and our lead pastor walked out of a cardboard model hung to the roof and it inspired me. I then looked at star charts and bought astronomy books. Then... we moved to Tennessee and I could see the stars even better without as much light pollution! So I suddenly found myself almost obsessed with Astrophysics and rocketry at 13 and then now 14 years old. Last summer I even took rocketry courses from NASA and now I joined the BMAC astronomy club! But even more than the stars, the ROCKETS are the thing that amazes me. You should try getting Universe SandBox two, I have it and even though it's pricey it's an awesome and realistic astrophysics simulator, (Soon to have rocketry) Anywho this is ChanceTHEBOSS, Out!


-Chance

P.S. I loved the Question you asked Elon Musk during his update talk with the BFR/BFS That was hilarious!

P.P.S. On a more personal note, do you have any beliefs?

It's a little weird seeing Major Jenny Ji talk about GPS as if it's the only global positioning satellite matrix up there. My cell phone uses the Russian satellites as well as the American ones. If the American satellites quit working I could still navigate everywhere.

NIce to see that fairing artwork but it will possibly kill a whale or dophin when it crashes in the ocean non recovered.  So much trash in the ocean, need more?  I just hate the amount of money they spend on bureaucracy instead of efficient design, built, launch. Miss those live cameras.  I surprised they are announcing in MPH.  Guess they are just ahead of using 300 year old english measurements.  This is 2019, Metric is used except in the old school Feet, inches.  Why don't they use Metric.  MPH? ( so old school, guess they cater to Trumps era of thinking). Their presentation of the (non-Geriatric management team) (younger people) is great.  KUDOS to making a great presentation with under 50 year olds.

A question I haven't seen addressed: why is Max Q on this and several other rockets significantly after the vehicle passes Mach 1? Shouldn't the maximum aerodynamic forces occur right as the vehicle goes trans sonic and experiences the added stress of normal shock across the vehicle's aerodynamic surfaces?

Thanks Tim. Great presentation, as always. We hope that your father recovers well, and quickly. Nobody can blame you, legitimately, for putting family first.

Taking a Tesla onto a beach can leave your car with long-term problems. Steel rusts, and Aluminium will oxidise at an alarming rate, if salt, water and Oxygen contact the metal. A friend has a fleet of veteran Rolls Royce cars, which had a number of Al components. He never hires them out if roads have been salted, because of the ensuing damage caused by the salt.
Wow what a beautiful launch. That close up cam that takes over just after the rocket disappears behind its own exhaust cloud is simply magnificently steady.
Cool fact about relative density: Water is a Kilo per liter, Whipped cream is 200g/liter and Liquefied H2 is 70g per liter. Somehow liquid hydrogen is 3x fluffier than even whipped cream!
